supporting.text: The human body undergoes involuntary muscle contractions and spasms due to the lack of oxygen to the brain during hanging, causing visible movement.

attacks.text: The human body undergoes involuntary muscle contractions and spasms due to the lack of oxygen to the brain during hanging, causing visible movement.
In some cases, the spinal cord is severed instantly during hanging, preventing any muscle contractions or movement.
Even with spinal cord severance, residual nerve activity can still cause minor muscle twitches.
The duration of hanging is often too short for significant oxygen deprivation to cause noticeable movements.
Studies show that even brief oxygen deprivation can trigger immediate involuntary muscle responses.

supporting.text: The sudden drop and jerk of the rope can cause the body to swing or twist, resulting in observable motion.

attacks.text: The sudden drop and jerk of the rope can cause the body to swing or twist, resulting in observable motion.
If the hanging is performed with precise calculation, the body may not swing due to minimal rope elasticity.
Even with minimal elasticity, involuntary muscle spasms post-death can cause slight movements.
Environmental factors like wind can cause motion, independent of the hanging mechanism.
Historical records show cases where bodies remained motionless due to immediate spinal cord severance.

supporting.text: Neurological reflexes, such as the gag reflex or limb twitching, may occur as the body reacts to the trauma of hanging.

attacks.text: Neurological reflexes, such as the gag reflex or limb twitching, may occur as the body reacts to the trauma of hanging.
Neurological reflexes cease quickly after brain death, which occurs rapidly in hanging due to oxygen deprivation.
Some reflexes, like spinal reflexes, can persist briefly even after brain death due to autonomous spinal cord activity.
The degree of movement depends on the type of hanging - complete suspension hanging typically causes faster unconsciousness and less movement than partial suspension.
Muscle paralysis agents used in some executions would prevent any reflexive movements regardless of neurological activity.

supporting.text: Gravity and the tension of the rope can cause the body to sway or rotate slightly after the initial drop, leading to movement.

attacks.text: Gravity and the tension of the rope can cause the body to sway or rotate slightly after the initial drop, leading to movement.
In many cases, the body quickly stabilizes due to the rigidity of the rope and the weight distribution, minimizing observable movement.
Environmental factors like wind or uneven rope tension can reintroduce movement even after initial stabilization.
The initial drop often causes the neck to break or the vertebrae to dislocate, resulting in immediate loss of muscle tension and reducing further movement.
In cases where the drop is insufficient to cause immediate spinal damage, muscle spasms or reflexes can still cause movement.

supporting.text: Historical and forensic records consistently document bodily movements during hangings, supporting the claim.

attacks.text: Historical and forensic records consistently document bodily movements during hangings, supporting the claim.
Some historical records may be exaggerated or based on unreliable eyewitness accounts, which could distort the perception of movement.
Forensic science has advanced to reliably document post-mortem movements, which are often mistaken for life signs during hangings.
The claim does not specify whether the movements are voluntary or involuntary, which is crucial for determining the validity of the observation.
Medical studies confirm that involuntary muscle contractions can occur after death, explaining observed movements during hangings.
